awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2019 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to  Nir Gadish is " Aspects of representation stability in topology and combinatorics". The host institution for the fellowship is Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the sponsoring scientist is Alexander Postnikov.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This projects produced new results and opened up novel research directions in a couple of topics:

  1. Exotic high-dimensional structures in the famous "moduli spaces of algebraic curves": in collaboration with M. Chan, C. Bibby and C. Yun, we develop a new computational tool that counts the number of top-dimensional holes in moduli spaces, accounting for new and exotic ways for curves over the complex numbers to deform. We were able to perform computer calculations, and produce tables counting the number of `top weight' classes of deformations of curves with 2 and 3 holes, with up to 10 marked points on them.
    Our calculations account for the symmetries induced by reordering the marked points, revealing a host of patterns that remain to be explained.
  2. Braiding of letters in words: in collaborations with D. Sinha, B. Walter and A. Ozbek, we produced a novel collection of ways to measure and distinuish between symmetries of objects, and equivalently, between loops in geometric objects.
    Motivating examples include braids and knots, which our measurements distinguish, reproducing and extending known knot invariants. With further work, this has the potential to settle open problems in knot theory, such as classifying the collection of finite type invariants over the integers and finite coefficients. Further examples of our theory illuminate collections of distinct particles in some ambient space, e.g. quantifying the complexity of motion planning algorithms for agents moving along a surface without collisions.

The grant further supported the PI's participation in the following outreach programs:

  1. Taught a mathematical recreation class at U. Michigan Math-Corps - free summer camp for local middleschoolers with poor access to math education.
  2. Mentored three high school students through an original research project conducted through the MIT PRIMES Program, culminating in a published paper in the Journal of Algebraic Combinatorics. All three students are now undergrads at Harvard or MIT.
  3. Mentored a `reading and research' course for an undergraduate student at U. Michigan, culminating a draft of a paper containing original results about distinguishing knots and links. The project involved 3D modeling, and student has now graduated and working in Silicone Valley.

Last Modified: 09/01/2023
Modified by: Nir Gadish
